entry.title: coat of arms of Anguilla (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the three dolphins on the coat of arms of Anguilla (pictured) represent "unity, strength and endurance", which is also the motto of the territory?

entry.title: Colonel Dyck (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Colonel Dyck commanded the Rhodesian and Zimbabwean armies before fighting as a mercenary in Mozambique in 2021 aged 77?

entry.title: Dili (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that in the early 2000s, the only settlement in East Timor with 24-hour electricity was its capital city Dili?

entry.title: Candidate for a Pullet Surprise (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the frequently plagiarized poems "Candidate for a Pullet Surprise" and "A Grandchild's Guide to Using Grandpa's Computer" are often cited in discussions of internet publishing ethics?

entry.title: Jamiat Ulema-e-Hind (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Jamiat Ulema-e-Hind divided into two factions in March 2008 due to differences between Arshad Madani and his nephew Mahmood Madani?

entry.title: Kristofferson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Kris Kristofferson's debut album, Kristofferson, was reissued with the title Me and Bobby McGee following the success of Janis Joplin's version of the song?

entry.title: Vladimír Škutina (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Czech television reporter and author Vladimír Škutina was arrested and imprisoned twice for his use of political satire?

entry.title: presidential campaign (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that during neo-Nazi David Duke's presidential campaign he was convicted, yelled at Jack Kemp, won a vice-presidential primary, switched parties, and had two running mates?
